thread.title: Anonymous hacker takes down 20% of the dark web
thread.title_full: Anonymous hacker takes down 20% of the dark web | Daily Mail Online

author: Harry Pettit For Mailonline
title: Anonymous hacker takes down 20% of the dark web
text:
A hacker claiming to be from the vigilante group Anonymous took 20 per cent of the dark web's websites offline.
The attack targeted more than 10,000 dark web sites that were selling or sharing child pornography.
The dark web is often associated with criminal activity and illicit content such as infamous online drug market Silk Road.
Scroll down for video
Each website that the hacker took down was left with a message of warning (pictured). The attacks took on a key infrastructure of the dark web called Freedom Hosting 2 last weekend
WHO ARE ANONYMOUS? Anonymous is a loosely associated international network of activist and hacktivist entities.
A website associated with the group describes it as 'an internet gathering' with 'a very loose and decentralised command structure that operates on ideas rather than directives.'
The group has become known for its hack attacks on government websites, extremist groups and corporate websites.
The attacks took on a key infrastructure of the dark web called Freedom Hosting 2 over the past weekend.
The component hosts 20 per cent of dark web sites and claims to have a 'zero tolerance policy to child pornography'.
Each website that the hacker took down was left with a message of warning.
'We are disappointed,' the message reads.
'We found while searching that your server is more than 50 per cent child porn.
'Moreover you host many scam sites, some of which are evidently run by yourself to cover hosting expenses.'
When the hacker found ten child pornography sites hosted on Freedom Hosting 2 they decided to shut down the whole network.
The hacker then leaked information from the sites, which the vigilante claims contained child pornography images and personal data that was for sale.
Information leaked includes all of the websites' system files and account information from their databases, which the hacker made available as a free download.
When the hacker found 10 child pornography sites hosted on Freedom Hosting 2 they decided to shut down the whole network. The hacker then leaked information from the sites (stock image)
User data from the websites reportedly contained thousands of unverified US government email addresses.
Twitter account @YourAnonNews, which boasts almost 1.7 million followers and is widely believed to be Anonymous's primary social media account, has denied responsibility.
'Since it has come up more than once, this account is not taking credit for this,' the account wrote in reply to a tweet from another user crediting Anonymous with the hack.
'Let credit go where it's due if it's so desired.'
Twitter account @YourAnonNews, which boasts almost 1.7 million followers and is widely believed to be Anonymous's primary social media account, has denied responsibility
But Anonymous has previously tackled dark web sites hosting child pornography.
The group targeted the original Freedom Hosting service in 2011 as part of 'Operation Dark Net', an attack on internet child pornography.
'Operation Death Eaters' in 2014 involved members of the group targeting paedophilia rings.
The group has attacked Islamic State and the Ku Klux Klan in recent years.
Anonymous is a loosely associated international network of activist and hacktivist entities.
A website associated with the group describes it as 'an Internet gathering' with 'a very loose and decentralised command structure that operates on ideas rather than directives.'
The group has become known for its hack attacks on government websites, extremist groups, and corporate websites.
The hackers responsible for last weekend's attack are yet to respond to MailOnline's request for comment.
WHAT IS THE DARK WEB'S TOR BROWSER? Tor - short for The Onion Router - is a seething matrix of encrypted websites that allows users to surf beneath the everyday internet with complete anonymity.
It uses numerous layers of security and encryption to render users anonymous online.
Normally, file sharing and internet browsing activity can be tracked by law enforcement through each user's unique IP address that can be traced back to an individual computer.
The Tor network hides the IP address and the activity of the user.
Most of the Web's information is buried far down on dynamically generated sites, unable to be found or seen by traditional search engines - sites or pages don't exist until created as the result of a specific search.
An Internet search is like dragging a net across the surface of the sea - a great deal of information is caught, but a majority is deep and therefore missed.
